thread.title: Women show solidarity with Muslims by donning headscarves on World Hijab Day | London Evening Standard
thread.title_full: Women show solidarity with Muslims by donning headscarves on World Hijab Day | London Evening Standard

author: Hatty Collier
title: Women show solidarity with Muslims by donning headscarves on World Hijab Day | London Evening Standard
text:
World Hijab Day 2017 - In pictures 1/9 
A child wears an American Flag head scarf at an event at City Hall for World Hijab Day in New York Spencer Platt/Getty Images 2/9 
New York City Police Officers Aml Elsokary (left) and Maritza Morales wear American Flag head scarfs at an event at City Hall for World Hijab Day Spencer Platt/Getty Images 3/9 
Sophia Herron wears an American Flag head scarf at an event at City Hall for World Hijab Day Spencer Platt/Getty Images 4/9 
Women wear American Flag head scarfs at an event at City Hall for World Hijab Day in New York Spencer Platt/Getty Images 5/9 
An Albanian Muslim woman poses (left) for a picture with other woman after inviting her to try on a headscarve (hijab) as a sign of support for women wearing hijabs during the World Hijab day in Tirana, Albania Armando Babani/EPA 6/9 
Sarah Rivali, 33, left, tries on a hijab with the help of Aicha Nahod, of Tunsia, on the campus of the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque Russell Contreras/AP 7/9 
A Liberian female soldier of the Armed forces of Liberia (C) with fellow muslim women pose for photograph during the celebration of World Hijab Day at a local stadium in Monrovia, Liberia Ahmed Jallanzo/EPA 8/9 
Albanian Muslim woman makes a selfie picture wearing a headscarve (hijab) as a sign of support for women wearing hijabs during the World Hijab day in Tirana, Albania Armando Babani/EPA 9/9 
Women wear American Flag head scarfs at an event at City Hall for World Hijab Day in New York Spencer Platt/Getty Images 
Activists showed their solidarity with Muslim women across the globe by donning headscarves to mark World Hijab Day. 
The international event, set up by New Yorker Nazma Khan, encourages non-Muslims and non-hijab-wearing Muslim women an opportunity to try the hijab for a day. 
Wednesday marked the fifth year of the annual event which was launched to show solidarity with Muslim women and celebrate religious tolerance. 
In New York, dozens of women wearing headscarves covered in scarves and stripes gathered on the steps of City Hall to mark the occasion. (Spencer Platt/Getty Images) 
Activists carried signs protesting against Islamophobia. 
Other demonstrations were held across the globe including in Liberia, Bosnia and Albania. 
Thousands of “solidarity selfies” were also posted on social media with the hashtags #IStand4Hijab and #WorldHijabDay. Thank you to my Christian Mum for standing by her Muslim daughter @WorldHijabDay #istand4hijab pic.twitter.com/PYTemkbXxa — Chloe Gülac (@chloegulac) February 1, 2017 #WorldHijabDay unlike many others, this was my choice, and for that I am thankful. It's a symbol of my faith and I am proud to wear it. pic.twitter.com/GlVTNbg1wr
